question: Kalgoorlie and Coolgardie - places famous for gold mines are located in:
note: Kalgoorlie-Boulder, known colloquially as just Kalgoorlie, is a city in the Goldfields-Esperance region of Western Australia, located 595 km (370 mi) east-northeast of Perth at the end of the Great Eastern Highway.

question: Tadoba national park known for sheltering tiger, panther and bear is located in:
note: In the Chandrapur district of Maharashtra lies the Tadoba Andhari National park which shelters around 43 tigers till date. The tiger reserve is one of the fifty tiger reserves in India which also happens to be the largest and oldest national park in the state. The name of the national park was kept after the name of the God “Tadoba” who is worshipped by the local tribes, and Andhari is the name of the river which meanders between the forest.

question: In geography who propounded the theory of convectional current hypothesis?
note: Arthur Holmes postulated convection current theory in the year 1928–29. It is widely accepted driving mechanism for continental drift(moving apart) which lead to the foundation of modern plate tectonics. His main objective was to find the scientific explanation of origin of the continent and oceans. But it is also widely accepted concept of mountain building.

question: Apatanis  are the tribes found in:
note: The Apatani, or Tanw, also known by Apa and Apa Tani, are a tribal group of people living in the Ziro valley in the Lower Subansiri district of Arunachal Pradesh in India.

question: Genoa is leading seaport of:
note: The Port of Genoa is the major Italian seaport and it's in competition with the ports of Marseille and Barcelona to be the biggest of the Mediterranean Sea. With a trade volume of 51.6 million tonnes, it is the busiest port of Italy by cargo tonnage.

question: Willandra Lakes Region a UNESCO Heritage site is located in:
note: The Willandra Lakes Region is a world heritage site in the far west region of New South Wales, Australia.

question: The headquarters of International Astronomical Union (IAU) is located in:
note: International Astronomical Union (IAU), senior body governing international professional astronomical activities worldwide, with headquarters in Paris. It was established in 1919 as the first of a series of international unions for the advancement of specific branches of science.

question: With which country in the year 2010 did India propose to develop a solar city in India?
note: Japan is the country with which India propose to develop a solar city in India.

question: The largest river of all the west flowing rivers of the peninsular India is:
note: Unlike east flowing major rivers of peninsular India, Narmada and Tapi (Tapti) are west flowing rivers running parallel to Vindhyas and Satpura Ranges and do not form deltas. Narmada is the third longest river of peninsular India with a length of 1312 kilometers.

question: Umiam Multipurpose Power Project is located in:
note: Umiam Lake (commonly known as Barapani Lake) is a reservoir in the hills 15 km (9.3 mi) north of Shillong in the state of Meghalaya, India. It was created by damming the Umiam River in the early 1960s. Umiam Multipurpose Power Project is located in Meghalaya.

question: The instrument which measures the intensity of solar radiation is called:
note: The solarimeter measures routine global solar radiation on a plane or level surface. It has a thermocouple junction-sensing element. The sensing element is coated with a highly stable carbon based non organic coating, which delivers excellent spectral absorption and long-term stability characteristics. The sensing element is housed under two concentric fitting glass domes.

question: Any wind blowing down the slope of a mountain is called:
note: A katabatic wind (named from the Greek word katabasis, meaning "descending") is the technical name for a drainage wind, a wind that carries high-density air from a higher elevation down a slope under the force of gravity. Such winds are sometimes also called fall winds; the spelling catabatic winds also occurs. Katabatic winds can rush down elevated slopes at hurricane speeds, but most are not as intense as that, and many are of the order of 10 knots (18 km/h) or less.

question: The zone of low atmospheric pressure and ascending air located at or near the equator is called:
note: The Inter Tropical Convergence Zone, or ITCZ, is a belt of low pressure which circles the Earth generally near the equator where the trade winds of the Northern and Southern Hemispheres come together. It is characterised by convective activity which generates often vigorous thunderstorms over large areas.

question: Indian state known as garden spice is:
note: Kerala is one of the beautiful state in India, it is known for its rich sources. Some of the spices are: Pepper, Vanilla, Cardamom and Clove.

question: Rajiv Gandhi Environment Award is given for outstanding contribution to:
options: Contribution in the development of Neat technology
note: This award is given to industrial units that make a significant contribution towards the development of new, or the innovative modification of existing, technologies or adoption and use of clean technologies and practices that substantially reduce or prevent environmental pollution. The award consist of a cash prize of Rupees Two lakh, trophy and citation.

question: Selves are dense tropical rain forest of:
note: A dense tropical rain forest usually having a cloud cover, especially one in the Amazon basin of South America.

question: Mahe and Yanam are the parts of the Union Territory of:
note: Puducherry lies in the southern part of the Indian Peninsula. The areas of Puducherry district and Karaikal district are bound by the state of Tamil Nadu, while Yanam district and Mahé district are enclosed by the states of Andhra Pradesh and Kerala respectively.

question: The most important breed of wool producing sheep in the world is:
note: By 1810 Australia boasted over 30,000 sheep and was one of the world Merino wool trade centers, together with the United States and Germany and by 1840 it was the most important Merino sheep grower, together with South Africa and New Zealand. The rest of the world focused on cross-bred and coarser-wool sheep breeds.

question: India's first marine national park is located in:
note: India's first Marine Wildlife Sanctuary and first Marine National Park were created in the Gulf of Kutch in 1980 and 1982, respectively. It is an archipelago of 42 tropical islands along the northern coast of Jamnagar district and the southern coast of Kutch.

question: Singareni Coalfields is located in :
note: Singareni opencast coal mines at Manuguru on Godavari Valley Coalfields is located in the districts of Adilabad, Karimnagar, Khammam and Warangal in the Indian state of Telangana. It is the only coalfield in South India. It lies in the basin of the Godavari River.

question: Seasonal movement of people and their herds from valley to mountain and vice-versa is known as:
note: Transhumance is a type of pastoralism or nomadism, a seasonal movement of livestock between fixed summer and winter pastures. In montane regions (vertical transhumance), it implies movement between higher pastures in summer and lower valleys in winter. Herders have a permanent home, typically in valleys. Generally only the herds travel, with a certain number of people necessary to tend them, while the main population stays at the base. In contrast, horizontal transhumance is more susceptible to being disrupted by climatic, economic, or political change.

question: Saar is a famous field in:
note: The Territory of the Saar Basin (German: Saarbeckengebiet, Saarterritorium; French: Le Territoire du Bassin de la Sarre) was a region of Germany occupied and governed by the United Kingdom and France from 1920 to 1935 under a League of Nations mandate.

question: The place/city located at the confluence of river Euphrates and Tigris is:
note: The place/city located at the confluence of river Euphrates and Tigris is Baghdad. Major canals that flowed from the Euphrates into the Tigris in the vicinity of Baghdad.

question: Which of the rock formations in India is the richest in fossil content?
note: The Marine Gondwana Fossil Park is a unique exposure of fossiliferous marine Permian rocks of the Talchir formation dating back to around 280-240 million years ago. Located in the Manendragarh area of Chattisgarh’s Koriya district, the fossil faunal assemblage is indicative of the transgression of sea in this part of India about 20 crores of years ago.

question: Pochampat irrigation project lies on:
note: The Sri Rama Sagar Project also known as the Pochampadu Project is an Indian flood-flow project on the Godavari.

question: Sandstone, conglomerate, limestone, shalepotash, loess, geyserites, chalk, coal, chert, halite are the examples of:
note: Sandstone, conglomerate, limestone, shalepotash, loess, geyserites, chalk, coal, chert, halite are the examples of Sedimentary Rocks.

question: The second most important agro based industry of India after textiles is:
note: India is the second largest sugar producing country of the world after Brazil. In 1840, the first sugar industry was set up in Betia (Bihar). Sugar production is known in India since ancient times, but modern sugar industry in India developed in first decade of the twentieth century.

question: As per 2011 Census of India the state which registered lowest sex ratio (female per thousand males) is:
note: Sex ratio is used to describe the number of females per 1000 of males. In the Population Census of 2011 it was revealed that the population ratio in India 2011 is 943 females per 1000 of males. Haryana has the lowest sex ratio (877) in Indian states while in union territory Daman & Diu has lowest sex ratio of 618.

question: The industrial region of India which has the predominance of metal industries is:
note: This region is located on the Chotanagpur plateau and extends over Jharkhand, Northern Orissa and western part of West Bengal. The birth and growth of this region is linked with the discovery of coal in Damodar Valley and iron ore in the Jharkhand-Orissa mineral belt. As both are found in close proximity, the region is known as the ‘Ruhr of India’.

question: The mean thickness of oceanic crust and continental crust is around:
note: The mean thickness of oceanic crust and continental crust is around 5 kilometer and 30 kilometer respectively.

question: Titagarh, Amlai and Nepanagar are known for:
note: Titagarh, Amlai and Nepanagar are known for Paper Industry.

question: The radiant energy received by the earth and its atmosphere from the sun is called:
note: The energy received by the earth is known as incoming solar radiation which in short is termed as insolation. As the earth is a geoid resembling a sphere, the sun's rays fall obliquely at the top of the atmosphere and the earth intercepts a very small portion of the sun's energy.

question: The layer of ocean water between the depth zone of 300 m- 1000 m characterized by sharp change of temperature in the vertical section of sea water is called:
note: Thermocline,  oceanic water layer in which water temperature decreases rapidly with increasing depth. A widespread permanent thermocline exists beneath the relatively warm, well-mixed surface layer, from depths of about 200 m (660 feet) to about 1,000 m (3,000 feet), in which interval temperatures diminish steadily.

question: The modern iron and steel industry in India had its beginning in 1870 when Bengal Iron Works Company was established in:
note: Modern steel making in India began with the setting of first blast furnace of India at Kulti in 1870 and production began in 1874, which was set up by Bengal Iron Works.Tata Iron and Steel Company (TISCO) was established by Dorabji Tata in 1907, as part of his father's conglomerate.

question: The planet which has maximum number of satellites is:
note: Saturn, the giant planet known for its rings, is now being celebrated for having the highest number of moons in the solar system – 145 total, after gaining 62 additional moons in May, according to extensive astronomer calculations. That's more "traditional moons" than the other planets combined.

question: Which planet is known as sister of earth?
note: Venus is very similar to Earth in size and mass - and so is sometimes referred to as Earth's sister planet - but Venus has a quite different climate.

question: The study of universe is called:
note: Cosmology is the scientific study of the large scale properties of the universe as a whole. It is the study of universe as a whole: its birth, growth, shape, size and eventual fate.

question: The large natural ecosystem comprised of abiotic (land, air , water and soils of the concerned habitat) and biotic (plants, animals and micro-organisms) is called:
note: The large natural ecosystem comprised of abiotic (land, air , water and soils of the concerned habitat) and biotic (plants, animals and micro-organisms) is called Biome.

question: The highest glacial lake of India located at the height of 17,745 feet in Garhwal Himalaya is:
note: The highest glacial lake of India is Devtal which is located at the height of 17,745 feet AMSL in Garhwal Himalaya.

question: Project Tiger, one of the premier conservation efforts in the country was launched on:
note: Project Tiger is a tiger conservation programme launched in 1 April, 1973 by the Government of India during Prime Minister Indira Gandhi's tenure.

question: In 1990 India ratified the world Heritage Convention of 1977 identifying four natural sites of outstanding universal value namely:
note: In 1990 India ratified the world Heritage Convention of 1977 identifying four natural sites of outstanding universal value namely Kaziranga National park (Assam), Keoladeo National Park (Rajasthan), Sundarbans Biosphere Reserve (West Bengal) and Nanda Devi Biosphere Reserve (Uttarakhand).

question: A group of populations of different species living in the same habitat and interacting with one another is called:
note: Organisms live within an ecological community, which is defined as an assemblage of populations of at least two different species that interact directly and indirectly within a defined geographic area.

question: Which river is known as Sorrow of Bihar?
note: The Kosi River is known as the "Sorrow of Bihar" as the annual floods affect about 21,000 km2 (8,100 sq mi) of fertile agricultural lands thereby disturbing the rural economy.

question: At present biosphere reserves that are included in world Heritage:

note: At present biosphere reserves that are included in world are Heritage Nilgiri, Nanda Devi, Nokrek, Gulf of Mannar, Sunderban, Simlipol and Pachmarhi.

question: Sand stone, Conglomerate, Limestone, Shale, Chalk and Coal are example of:
note: Sedimentary rocks are formed by the accumulation of sediments. There are three basic types of sedimentary rocks. Clastic sedimentary rocks such as breccia, conglomerate, sandstone, siltstone, and shale are formed from mechanical weathering debris.

question: Dr. Waldimir Koppen - the great climatologist of Austria suggested in his new scheme of climatic classification:
note:
The Koppen climate classification scheme divides climates into five main climate groups:
I. tropical
II. dry
III. temperate
IV. continental
V. polar

question: The largest Indian mammal is:
note: The Asian (or Indian) elephant is the largest terrestrial mammal in Asia, with a maximum shoulder height of 3.2 m. It is smaller than the African elephant (Loxodonta africana), with relatively smaller ears, and the head (not the shoulder) is the highest part of the body.

question: The Indian Council of Forestry Research and Education (ICFRE) were created in:
note: ICFRE is the largest organisation responsible for forestry research in India. ICFRE was created in 1987, under the Central Ministry of Environment and Forests (India), to direct and manage research and education in forestry sector in India. ICFRE is headed by a Director General with headquarters at Dehradun.

question: The inner planets include:
note: The inner four planets are called terrestrial planets. That means that they are like the earth in some ways. The terrestrial planets are Mercury, Venus, Earth, Mars, and the earth's moon have similar compositions and densities. These planets are close to the sun, rocky, and dense.

question: The mean thickness of oceanic crust is:
note: The mean thickness of oceanic crust is 5 kilometer.

question: The first large scale modern machine tool factory set up in public sector is :
note: The Hindustan Machine Tools (H.M.T.) is the first large scale modem machine tool factory set up in public sector at Bangalore in 1953, with Swiss collaboration.

question: The first shore-based steel plant in India is:

Vizag Steel Plant is the only Indian shore-based steel plant and is situated on 33,000 acres (13,000 ha), and is poised to expand to produce up to 20 MT in a single campus.

question: Golden Quadrilateral Comprising National Highways connects:
note: Golden Quadrilateral Comprising National Highways connects Delhi-Mumbai-Chennai-Kollata-Delhi (by six lane wuper highways).

question: The diesel locomotive works engaged in producing diesel locos is located in:

question: The Chambal Valley Project is a joint venture of:

question: The largest satellite in the solar system is:
note: Ganymede is by far the largest moon and orbits around planet Jupiter with a diameter of 5,262 kilometers.

question: The study of moon is called:
note: In Greek, our moon is named "Selene," as is the moon goddess of ancient Greek mythology. The English word "selenology," or the study of the moon's geology, derives from it.

question: The portion of incident radiation (energy) without heating that surface reflected back from a surface of a body is called:
note: The ratio between the total solar radiation falling (incident) upon a surface and the amount reflected without heating the earth, is called ALBEDO (expressed as a decimal or as a percentage). The earth's average albedo is about 0.4 (40%); that is, 4/10 of the solar radiation is reflected back into space.

question: The Mountain system of Alps, Carpathians, Transylvanian, Balkans are located in:
note: The Mountain system of Alps, Transylvanian, Balkans are located in Europe.

question: The line at which a day is lost or gained is called:
options: Line of Control day and night
note: The International Date Line (IDL) is an imaginary line of demarcation on the surface of Earth that runs from the North Pole to the South Pole and demarcates the change of one calendar day to the next. It passes through the middle of the Pacific Ocean, roughly following the 180° line of longitude but deviating to pass around some territories and island groups.

question: The Vernal equinox occurs on:
note: The Vernal equinox occurs on March 21.

question: The autumnal equinox occurs on:
note: The autumnal equinox occurs on September 23.

question: The predominant gases that constitute the sun are:
note: The predominant element in the Sun is hydrogen, and then helium: by mass, it is 70% hydrogen, 28% helium.

question: Vedanthangal Bird Sanctuary is located in:

question: The largest port of India is:

question: Dul Hasti Project and Salal project are located at:
note: Dulhasti power station is run-of-the-river with pondage scheme with an installed capacity of 390 MW (3 X 130MW) to harness the hydropower potential of river Chenab. It is located in Kishtwar district of Jammu & Kashmir.

question: Madumalai Sanctuary is located in:
note: The Mudumalai National Park and Wildlife Sanctuary also a declared tiger reserve, lies on the northwestern side of the Nilgiri Hills, in Nilgiri District, about 150 kilometres north-west of Coimbatore city in Tamil Nadu. It shares its boundaries with the states of Karnataka and Kerala.

question: The headquarters of North Western Railway is located in:
note: North Western Railway has its zonal headquarters at Jaipur. Furthermore, the zone is divided into four divisions headquartered at Jaipur, Ajmer, Bikaner and Jodhpur.

question: First Metro Railway was inaugurated in Kolkata:
note: The underwater metro plan was thought of when the first metro service was inaugurated in Kolkata in October 24, 1984 by former Prime Minister Indira Gandhi.

question: India's first Stock Exchange Bombay Stock Exchange was established in:
note: The Bombay Stock Exchange, popularly known as BSE, is the oldest one in Asia. BSE was established in 1875 as The Native Share and Stock Brokers Association. The Tokyo Stock Exchange was established in 1878. The Bombay Stock Exchange, popularly known as BSE, is the oldest one in Asia.

question: The index which refers to moisture deficit or surplus in an area is called:
note: The term used instead of 'moisture budget', e.g. by C. W. Thornthwaite (1955), and calculated from the aridity and humidity indices, as I m = 100 × (S − D)/PE, where I m is the moisture index, S is the water surplus, D is the water deficit, and PE is the potential evapotranspiration.

question: The study of plant communities in relation to their habitats of a given ecosystem is known as:
note: Synecology is the study of group of organisms of different species which are associated together as a unit in form of a community. Also known as community ecology. Autecology helps us to understand the relationships between individual plants and environment.

question: Primary Producers fall in two categories e.g.
note: Phototrophs and chemotrophs are two types of nutritional groups found in the environment. Most phototrophs are autotrophs, using the energy from sunlight to produce their food. Chemotrophs oxidize inorganic compounds or organic compounds as their energy source. They are the primary producers of food chains.

question: The Naharkatiya oil field is located in:
note: Naharkatia (also spelled as Naharkatia or Nahorkatiya) is a town and a town area committee in Dibrugarh district in the Indian state of Assam. It is well known for petroleum and gas reserves. Earlier, Duliajan, the head office town of Oil India Limited was in its circle.

question: The largest mangrove forest in the world is located in:
note: The Sundarbans is a mangrove area in the delta formed by the confluence of Ganges, Brahmaputra and Meghna Rivers in the Bay of Bengal. It spans from the Hooghly River in India's state of West Bengal to the Baleswar River in Bangladesh.

question: The water body separating Andaman and Nicobar is known as:

question: Which industry is developed in Shahdol and Nepanagar?

question: Sun's rays can make right angle only up to 23(1/2) and South latitudes because:

question: The Richter scale on which intensity/magnitude of a quake is measured was developed in:
note: Richter scale (ML), quantitative measure of an earthquake’s magnitude (size), devised in 1935 by American seismologists Charles F. Richter and Beno Gutenberg. The earthquake’s magnitude is determined using the logarithm of the amplitude (height) of the largest seismic wave calibrated to a scale by a seismograph.

question: Masai Tribes are found in:
note: Maasai are a Nilotic ethnic group inhabiting northern, central and southern Kenya and northern Tanzania. They are among the best known local populations internationally due to their residence near the many game parks of the East African Great Lakes, and their distinctive customs and dress.

question: The largest producers of coffee in the world is:
note: Brazil is the largest coffee producing country in the world, and the history comes from last 150 years.

question: The law which states that wave-length of maximum radiation is inversely proportional to the absolute of the emitting body is known as:
note: The Wien's Displacement Law states that a black body having a wavelength (λmax) carrying the maximum energy is inversely proportional to the absolute temperature (T).

question: Exfoliation is a type of:
note: Exfoliation occurs as cracks develop parallel to the land surface a consequence of the reduction in pressure during uplift and erosion. It is a type of physical weathering.

question: World Water Day is observed on:
note: World Water Day is an annual UN observance day (always on 22 March) that highlights the importance of freshwater. The day is used to advocate for the sustainable management of freshwater resources.

question: The largest state of India(area wise) is:
note: Rajasthan is a state in northern India. The state covers an area of 342,239 square kilometres (132,139 sq mi) or 10.4% of the total geographical area of India. It is the largest Indian state by area and the seventh largest by population.

question: Hyderabad (in Telangana) is located on the bank:
note: Situated in the southern part of Telangana in southeastern India, Hyderabad is 1,566 kilometres (973 mi) south of Delhi, 699 kilometres (434 mi) southeast of Mumbai, and 570 kilometres (350 mi) north of Bangalore by road. question: The River Cauvery rises on the western edge of:

question: Ankleshwar Basin (offshore) oil-fields is located in:
note: Ankleshwar Basin (offshore) oil-fields is located in Gujarat.

question: India is divided into:
note: There are nine PIN zones in India, including eight regional zones and one functional zone (for the Indian Army). The first digit of the PIN code indicates the region. The second digit indicates the sub-region, and the third digit indicates the sorting district within the region.

question: Rail coach factory is located in:
note: Rail Coach Factory at Kapurthala in the Indian state of the Punjab is located on the Jalandhar-Firozpur line.

question: India's first Atomic power plant is:
note: Tarapur Atomic Power Station (T. A. P. S.) was the first nuclear power plant in India. The construction of the plant was started in 1962 and the plant went operational in 1969. The 320 MW Tarapur nuclear power station housed two 160 MW boiling water reactors (BWRs), the first in Asia.

question: Where is the volcanic Mt. St. Helens situated?

question: Temperate grasslands of Eurasia are called:

question: The circulation and movement of soluble inorganic matter (nutrients) derived from sedimentary and atmospheric phases and reservoirs through organic phase of various biotic components and finally their return to inorganic phase is collectively called:
note: The circulation and movement of soluble inorganic matter (nutrients) derived from sedimentary and atmospheric phases and reservoirs through organic phase of various biotic components and finally their return to inorganic phase is collectively called Biogeochemical Cycles.

question: The middle zone of the earth with a thickness of 2780 km having an average density of 5.6 is known as:
note: The middle zone of the earth with a thickness of 2780 Km having an average density of 5-6 is known as Pyrosphere.

question: The instrument which records the seismic waves generated by the occurrence of earth-quakes is called:
note: Seismograph, instrument that makes a record of seismic waves caused by an earthquake, explosion, or other Earth-shaking phenomenon. A record produced by a seismograph on a display screen or paper printout is called a seismogram.

question: Wild Ass Sanctuary is situated in
note: Indian Wild Ass Sanctuary also known as the Wild Ass Wildlife Sanctuary is located in the Little Rann of Kutch in the Gujarat state of India. It is spread over an area of 4954 km² .

question: The headquarters of North Eastern Railway is:
note: The North Eastern Railway is one of the 18 railway zones in India. It is headquartered at Gorakhpur and comprises Lucknow, Varanasi and Izzatnagar or Bareilly division.

question: The Western Ghats are also known as:

question: The major peaks like Mt. Everest, Kanchenjunga, Makalu, Dhaulagiri, Mansalu, Chooyu, Nanga Parbat and Annapurna all are situated in:
note: The major peaks like Mt. Everest, Kanchenjunga, Makalu, Dhaulagiri, Mansalu, Chooyu, Nanga Parbat and Annapurna all are situated in The Greater Himalayas (Himadri).

question: The Highest peak of the Karakoram Range is:

question: Vembanad Lake is located in:

question: The most important coal field in India is:

question: World Environment Day is observed on:
note: World Environment Day (WED) is celebrated on the 5th of June every year, and is the United Nation's principal vehicle for encouraging awareness and action for the protection of our environment.

question: McMohan Line lies between which of the following countries?
note: It is currently the effective boundary between China and India, although its legal status is disputed by the Chinese government. The line is named after Henry McMahon, foreign secretary of British India and the chief negotiator of the convention at Simla.

question: India is the seventh largest country in the world and occupies:

question: The imaginary line joining the land projecting towards the sea which is the landward limit of internal seawater is called:
note: The imaginary line joining the land projecting towards the sea which is the landward limit of internal seawater is called Base Line.

question: The Beas project consisting of Beas-Satluj link and pong dam at Beas is the joint venture of:

question: The Nagarjunsagar Dam project is located on:

question: River Damodar is a tributary of:

question: CGWB stands for:

Central Ground Water Board was established in 1970 by renaming the Exploratory Tube wells Organization under the Ministry of Agriculture, Government of India. It was merged with the Ground Water Wing of the Geological Survey of India during 1972.

question: Which planet is called watery planet?
note: If you look down at our planet from outer space, most of what you see is water; 71% of the planet's surface is covered by ocean and it is because of this that the Earth is sometimes called "the water planet". Only about three-tenths of our globe is covered with land.

question: The crude Birth Rate is defined as:
options: No. of births per 10 thousand populations
No. of births per 20 thousand populations
No. of births per 50 thousand populations
No. of births per thousand populations
note: The crude birth rate is the number of live births occurring among the population of a given geographical area during a given year, per 1,000 mid-year total population of the given geographical area during the same year.

question: The Himalayas were uplifted from the:
note: The excessive shrinking of the geosynclines, caused folding and the surplus sediments were raised as the Himalayan mountains. The Himalayan uplift out of the tethys sea and the subsidence of the northern flank of the peninsular plateau resulted in the formation of a large basin.

question: In India the percentage of population below poverty line is:

question: Sundarban was declared a World Heritage Site because of its:

question: The Greenhouse effect gases trap only the heat of:
note: The Greenhouse effect gases trap only the heat of Solar Radiation.

question: Lignite is a type of:
note: Lignite, often referred to as brown coal, is a soft, brown, combustible, sedimentary rock formed from naturally compressed peat. It is considered the lowest rank of coal due to its relatively low heat content. It has a carbon content around 60-70%.

question: One horned rhinoceros is found in the states of:
note: The preferred habitat of an Indian rhinoceros is alluvial flood plains and areas containing tall grasslands along the foothills of the Himalayas. Formerly, extensively distributed in the Gangetic plains, today the species is restricted to small habitats in Indo-Nepal terai and northern West Bengal and Assam.

question: Which plateau lies between the Aravalli and the Vindhya ranges?

The southern boundary is demarcated by the Vindhya Range with Kaimur Hills in the eastern extent. The Malwa plateau lies between Aravalis and Vindhyas.

question: Green Index has been developed by:

question: Ken, Betwa and Chambal are the rivers which merge with:

question: Project Tiger in India was started in:
note: One of the most intensive conservation efforts in India, Project Tiger was launched in 1973. It envisaged the setting up of tiger reserves to help in maintaining the population of tigers. As per estimates, the number of tigers was about 40,000 at the beginning of the 20th century.

question: A river drains the water collected from a specific area which is called its:
note: A river drains the water collected from a specific area, which is called its 'catchment area'. An area drained by a river and its tributaries is called a drainage basin. The boundary line separating one drainage basin from the other is known as the watershed.

question: The low flat central area of a basin of inland drainage is called:
note: Playas occupy the flat central basins of desert plains. They require interior drainage to a zone where evaporation greatly exceeds inflow. A saline playa may be called a salt flat, salt marsh, salada, salar, salt pan, alkali flat, or salina.

question: The only South American nation through which both the Equator and the Tropic of Capricorn pass through?
note: The Tropic of Capricorn lies at 23.5° south of the equator and runs through Australia, Chile, southern Brazil (Brazil is the only country that passes through both the equator and a tropic), and northern South Africa.

note: India share its longest border with Bangladesh and that is 4093 km. Total length of the boundary, India shares with other countries is 15200 km.

It’s also the site of technology-focused institutions centered around Palo Alto's Stanford University.

question: The highest percentage decadal growth rate of population as per 2011 Census was registered by:

question: What is the difference between the Indian Standard time and Greenwich Standard Time?
note: The difference between GMT and IST is it varies in time duration that is IST is 5 hours and 30 minutes ahead of GMT.

question: Wainganga river is a tributary of:

question: The state of atmosphere in relation to its water vapour content refers to:
note: Relative Humidity is the amount of water vapour present in air. Water vapour, the gaseous state of water, is generally invisible to the human eye. Humidity indicates the likelihood for precipitation, dew, or fog to be present. The amount of water vapour needed to achieve saturation increases as the temperature increases.

note: It takes sunlight an average of 8 minutes and 20 seconds to reach to the Earth.

question: Garampani Wildlife Sanctuary is located in:
note: Garampani Wildlife Sanctuary is a 6.05-square-kilometre (2.34 sq mi) wildlife sanctuary located in Karbi Anglong district, Assam, India. It is 25 km (16 mi) from Golaghat.

question: Sabarmati, Mahi, Narmada and Tapti rivers form:
note: Sabarmati, Mahi, Narmada, and Tapti rivers are known for forming potholes. Potholes are natural depressions or cavities that are formed in the riverbeds due to the erosional action of flowing water carrying rocks and sediment. Over time, the swirling action of water, along with the abrasion caused by rocks and pebbles, creates these cylindrical or hemispherical cavities in the bedrock of the river. Potholes are a unique geological feature that can be found in various river systems around the world.

question: The Barak River is a famous river of:
note: The principal tributaries of the Barak in India are the Jirl, the Dhaleshwari, the Singla, the Longai, the Sonai and the Katakhal. From its source in the Manipur Hills near Mao Songsang, the river is known as the Barak River.

question: Between the valley of Narmada river in the north and the Tapti in the south lies:

question: Scunthorpe and Frodingham are:

question: The average density of the outer-most layer (zone)- that is crust- of the earth is:

question: India's three fourths of the total annual rainfall are received during:

question: Which is known as thunder cloud?

note: Cement industry is generally known as source of raw material.

question: The word "tsunami"belongs to:

question: The national Thermal Power Corporation (NTPC) was set up in:

question: The first of the fourteen biosphere reserves of India which was established in 1986 is:

question: The average rainfall in India is about:
note: The average rainfall in India is about 125 cm.

question: The Gneiss is a coarse grained:
note: Gneiss is a common and widely distributed type of metamorphic rock. Gneiss is formed by high temperature and high-pressure metamorphic processes acting on formations composed of igneous or sedimentary rocks. Orthogneiss is gneiss derived from igneous rock (such as granite).

note: As per 2011 census data lowest decadal growth rate (state) has been registered in Kerala (4.86%).

question: The crust and the upper-most part of the mantle up to a depth of 200 km from the surface of the earth is called:

question: The Earth's core is made up of very heavy material mostly constituted by:

question: Earthquakes waves are of two types namely:
note: The two main types of waves are body waves and surface waves. Body waves can travel through the earth's inner layers, but surface waves can only move along the surface of the planet like ripples on water. Earthquakes radiate seismic energy as both body and surface waves.

question: Granite and Basalt are the examples of:

Both are igneous rocks, which means that they cooled from a magma (the earth gets very hot just below the surface, and there is lots of liquid rock available). Both are made up of minerals from the silicate group, so both have large amounts of silicon and oxygen.

question: The Regur soil is:

question: The flood plain along river banks formed by newer alluvium is called:

question:

II. Afforestation
III. Encouraging the use of chemical fertilizers
IV. Limiting shifting cultivation
note: Measures that are effective for soil conservation in India are afforestation and Limiting shifting cultivation. Afforestation is the establishment of a forest or stand of trees (forestation) in an area where there was no previous tree cover. Shifting cultivation is an agricultural system in which plots of land are cultivated temporarily, then abandoned and allowed to revert to their natural vegetation while the cultivator moves on to another plot.

question: The natural region which holds the Indian subcontinent is
